etymology.description: pictogram: a kneeling person from side view; similar but unrelated to 欠 and 女; see also 即; unrelated to 报.
etymology.interpretation: Depicts a person kneeling in profile, with the bent leg and upright torso stylized into the compact form. As a component it often signals the seal/kneeling-person radical in right-side positions, without implying any relation to look-alikes such as 欠 or 女.

examples.chinese: 古文字里，"卩"像侧身跪着的人(古文字裡，"卩"像側身跪著的人)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔ wénzì lǐ, "卩" xiàng cèshēn guìzhe de rén.
examples.english: In ancient scripts, "卩" looks like a person kneeling in profile.

examples.chinese: 在现代汉字中，卩多作部首，常放在字的右侧(在現代漢字中，卩多作部首，常放在字的右側)。
examples.pinyin: Zài xiàndài hànzì zhōng, jié duō zuò bùshǒu, cháng fàng zài zì de yòucè.
examples.english: In modern Chinese characters, 卩 mostly functions as a radical, often placed on the right side.

examples.chinese: 例如，即、却等字都含有卩(例如，即、卻等字都含有卩)。
examples.pinyin: Lìrú, jí, què děng zì dōu hányǒu jié.
examples.english: For example, characters like 即 and 却 contain 卩.
